definition:
Let $U \subset \mathbb{C}$ be a domain and let $a \in \mathbb{C}$. A
function $f\colon U \to \mathbb{C}$ has a *pole* at $a$ if it can be
represented by a Laurent series centered about $a$ with only finitely
many terms of negative exponent; that is,
$$f(z) = \sum_{k=-n}^\infty c_k (z-a)^k$$ in some nonempty deleted
neighborhood of $a$, with $c_{-n} \neq 0$, for some $n \in \mathbb{N}$.
The number $n$ is called the *order* of the pole. A *simple pole* is a
pole of order 1.
